definitions: coming after the tenth in position, time, or order in a sequence
constituting number eleven in a sequence or series of items
examples: She finished in eleventh place in the marathon
The eleventh hour brought unexpected developments
The eleventh chapter contains crucial plot revelations
We meet on the eleventh day of each month

definitions: having a small, delicate build with charming or mischievous features
characteristic of or relating to elves in folklore and fantasy
examples: Her elfin face lit up with an impish smile
The child had delicate elfin features and sparkling eyes
The forest had an elfin quality in the moonlight
They discovered elfin markings on the ancient stones

definitions: brought forth or drawn out through deliberate action or questioning
examples: The elicited responses revealed surprising patterns
Her elicited confession shocked the investigators

definitions: having the right qualifications or meeting the requirements for something
considered suitable or desirable for marriage or romantic partnership
examples: All eligible voters should register before the deadline
Students with high grades are eligible for scholarships
He was considered the most eligible bachelor in town
Several eligible candidates applied for the position

definitions: of the highest quality, skill, or social standing in a group
belonging to or characteristic of a select privileged group
examples: Elite athletes train for years to compete internationally
The university attracts elite students from around the world
The elite members enjoyed exclusive privileges and access
Elite society gathered at the prestigious annual gala

definitions: having the shape of an ellipse or oval form
examples: The planet follows an elliptic orbit around the sun
The elliptic leaves distinguish this species from others

definitions: having the elongated shape of an ellipse or oval
using or characterized by omission of words that are understood
indirect or cryptic in expression rather than straightforward
examples: The elliptical shape of the track suited distance runners
Mars has an elliptical orbit around the sun
Her elliptical writing style requires careful interpretation
The elliptical sentence omitted the understood subject
His elliptical remarks left everyone confused about his intentions
The politician gave elliptical answers to direct questions

definitions: stretched out or extended in length compared to width
examples: The elongate leaves of the willow tree swayed gracefully
Scientists discovered an elongate fossil in the rock formation

definitions: made longer or stretched out in one dimension
having unusual or excessive length relative to width
examples: The artist painted elongated figures in the surrealist style
The elongated shadows stretched across the courtyard
The giraffe has an elongated neck for reaching high leaves
Her elongated fingers made her perfect for playing piano

definitions: having or showing the ability to use language clearly and effectively
clearly expressing or indicating something without words
examples: The eloquent speaker captivated the audience for hours
Her eloquent defense convinced the jury of his innocence
His eloquent silence spoke volumes about his disapproval
The ruins provided eloquent testimony to ancient glory

definitions: difficult to find, catch, or achieve despite persistent efforts
difficult to remember, understand, or define precisely
examples: The elusive criminal evaded capture for years
Success remained elusive despite their best efforts
The elusive meaning of the poem puzzled scholars
Sleep was elusive after the disturbing news

definitions: showing playful mischief or supernatural charm
of or relating to elves in mythology and fantasy
examples: Her elvish grin suggested she was planning something
The child had an elvish quality that charmed everyone
The elvish language in the fantasy novel was fully developed
They studied elvish lore and ancient magical traditions

definitions: abnormally thin and weak, especially from illness or lack of food
examples: The emaciated refugees desperately needed food and medical care
His emaciated frame showed the effects of prolonged illness

definitions: freed from legal, social, or political restrictions
showing freedom from traditional social conventions or attitudes
examples: The emancipated slaves began building new lives in freedom
Emancipated minors can make their own legal decisions
She was an emancipated woman who defied social expectations
Their emancipated views shocked conservative society members

definitions: feeling self-conscious, awkward, or ashamed in a social situation
examples: She felt embarrassed when she tripped on stage
He was too embarrassed to admit his mistake publicly

definitions: causing someone to feel awkward, self-conscious, or ashamed
examples: The embarrassing photos spread quickly on social media
It was an embarrassing moment when he forgot her name

definitions: facing sustained attack, criticism, or difficult circumstances
prepared or fortified for defense against attack
examples: The embattled CEO faced calls for his resignation
The embattled city withstood months of siege
The embattled fortress stood against repeated assaults
Embattled troops held their defensive positions firmly

definitions: fixed firmly and deeply in a surrounding mass or material
integrated as an essential part of a surrounding whole
examples: The fossils were embedded in layers of sedimentary rock
Shrapnel remained embedded in his shoulder after surgery
Embedded journalists traveled with military units during combat
Cultural values are deeply embedded in social practices

definitions: stolen or misappropriated through breach of trust in position
examples: The embezzled funds were traced to offshore accounts
Embezzled money had been used for personal luxuries

definitions: serving as a symbol or typical example of something
examples: The bald eagle is emblematic of American freedom
Her success story is emblematic of immigrant achievement

definitions: given a tangible or visible form to an abstract concept
represented or expressed in a concrete or physical form
examples: The statue embodied the spirit of liberty and justice
Their embodied values shaped the organization's culture
The embodied cognition theory links thinking to physical experience
Ancient wisdom was embodied in their architectural designs

definitions: given courage or confidence to do something challenging or risky
examples: The emboldened protesters marched toward the capitol building
Success in the first project left them emboldened

definitions: decorated with a design that is raised above the surface
examples: The embossed lettering on the invitation felt elegant
Her embossed business cards made a professional impression

definitions: deeply involved in a difficult, complicated, or compromising situation
examples: The company became embroiled in a lengthy legal battle
She found herself embroiled in office politics

definitions: relating to an embryo or its early development stage
in a rudimentary or undeveloped state but showing potential
examples: Embryonic stem cells can develop into any cell type
The embryonic development occurs during the first trimester
The project is still in its embryonic stages
Their embryonic relationship showed promise for the future

definitions: becoming apparent or prominent; in the process of emerging
arising as an unpredictable result of complex system interactions
examples: Emergent technologies are reshaping the business landscape
The emergent leader quickly gained support from colleagues
Consciousness is an emergent property of brain activity
Emergent behavior in ant colonies demonstrates collective intelligence

definitions: coming into existence or beginning to be known
becoming important or prominent in a particular sphere
examples: Emerging markets offer new investment opportunities
Scientists study emerging diseases to prevent pandemics
She is an emerging artist in the contemporary scene
Emerging economies are driving global growth patterns

definitions: famous and respected within a particular sphere or profession
examples: The eminent scientist received numerous international awards
Several eminent scholars contributed to the research project

definitions: relating to or involving a person's emotions or feelings
showing strong feelings, especially being easily moved to tears
arousing or intended to arouse strong feelings
examples: Emotional intelligence helps in understanding others better
The emotional impact of the loss was devastating
She became emotional during the farewell speech
He's too emotional to make rational decisions now
The movie's emotional scenes brought audiences to tears
Their emotional appeal swayed public opinion significantly

definitions: showing no emotion or feelings; completely impassive or unresponsive
examples: His emotionless face gave no hint of his thoughts
She delivered the tragic news in an emotionless voice

definitions: arousing or able to arouse intense feeling or strong emotion
examples: The emotive language in his speech stirred the crowd
Abortion remains an emotive issue in political debates

definitions: showing ability to understand and share the feelings of another person
examples: The empathetic counselor helped her through difficult times
Being empathetic makes you a better friend and listener

definitions: having the ability to understand and share another's feelings
examples: Her empathic nature made her an excellent therapist
The empathic connection between them was immediately obvious

definitions: given special importance, value, or prominence to something
examples: The emphasised points in the lecture will be on the exam
Her emphasised words carried extra weight in the discussion

definitions: given special importance or prominence in expression or treatment
examples: The emphasized text appears in bold typeface
The emphasized syllables give the poem its rhythm

definitions: showing or giving emphasis through force or clarity of expression
definite and clear in a way that shows determination
examples: She made an emphatic gesture to silence the room
His emphatic denial left no room for doubt
The team's emphatic victory secured their championship title
The vote was an emphatic rejection of the proposal

definitions: based on observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic
examples: Empirical evidence supports the new medical treatment
The study used empirical methods to test the hypothesis

definitions: having a paid job or being in regular work
being used or applied for a particular purpose
examples: All employed workers receive health insurance benefits
The employed population has grown steadily this year
The methods employed in this study were innovative
Various techniques were employed to achieve the goal

definitions: given official authority or legal power to do something
made stronger and more confident in controlling life and rights
examples: The empowered committee can make binding decisions
Legally empowered agents acted on the company's behalf
She felt empowered after completing the leadership program
The empowered students took charge of their learning

definitions: containing nothing; not filled or occupied with anything
having no meaning, value, or substance despite appearance
having no people present; vacant or unoccupied
examples: The empty bottle rolled across the floor
Her empty stomach growled during the meeting
His empty promises meant nothing to her anymore
The speech was full of empty rhetoric and clichés
The empty house felt cold and unwelcoming
Empty streets gave the city an eerie atmosphere

definitions: providing the means or opportunity to make something possible
allowing or encouraging harmful behavior by avoiding consequences
examples: The enabling technology made remote work feasible
New enabling legislation supported small business growth
Her enabling behavior prevented him from facing consequences
Stop enabling his addiction by making excuses

definitions: filled with a feeling of love or deep attraction for someone or something
examples: He was completely enamored with his new colleague
She became enamored of French culture during her visit

definitions: enclosed or covered completely in a case or protective covering
examples: The fossil was encased in solid rock for millions of years
Delicate electronics were encased in waterproof housing

definitions: placed under a spell or having magical qualities
filled with delight and wonder as if by magic
examples: The enchanted forest was home to mythical creatures
An enchanted sword glowed with mysterious power
The children were enchanted by the puppet show
She lived in an enchanted world of imagination

definitions: delightfully charming or attractive in a magical or captivating way
examples: The enchanting melody filled the concert hall
She had an enchanting smile that lit up the room

definitions: formed a circle around something or surrounded it completely
examples: The ancient city was encircled by massive stone walls
Her wrist was encircled by a delicate gold bracelet

definitions: forming or moving in a complete circle around something
examples: The encircling mountains protected the valley from storms
Encircling arms provided comfort during difficult times

definitions: surrounded or closed off on all sides by walls or barriers
placed inside something else, especially with a letter
examples: The enclosed garden provided privacy from neighbors
An enclosed porch extended their living space year-round
Please find the enclosed documents for your review
The enclosed check covers the full payment amount

definitions: including or covering completely a large number or range of things
examples: The encompassing study examined all aspects of climate change
Her encompassing knowledge impressed the interview panel

definitions: given support, confidence, or hope to someone
stimulated or helped to develop or increase
examples: The encouraged students performed better on their exams
She felt encouraged by the positive feedback
The encouraged growth in tourism boosted the economy
Encouraged development of renewable energy continues
